articles.headline: Lilly Said to Be Near $1.4 Billion U.S. Settlement
articles.snippet: The sum would settle criminal and civil charges that Lilly illegally marketed Zyprexa for unauthorized uses.
articles.abstract: The sum would settle criminal and civil charges that Lilly illegally marketed Zyprexa for unauthorized uses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eli Lilly, the drug company, is expected to agree as soon as Thursday to pay $1.4 billion to settle criminal and civil charges that it illegally marketed its blockbuster antipsychotic drug Zyprexa for unauthorized use in patients particularly vulnerable to its risky side effects.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Alex Berenson

articles.headline: Apple’s Chief Takes a Medical Leave
articles.snippet: Saying his health issues were “more complex” than he originally thought, Steven P. Jobs is taking a leave until the end of June.
articles.abstract: Saying his health issues were “more complex” than he originally thought, Steven P. Jobs is taking a leave until the end of June.
articles.lead_paragraph: Casting a pall over one of the world’s most closely watched companies, Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple, said on Wednesday that he was taking a leave of absence because of health concerns.

articles.headline: Bank of America May Receive More Bailout Money
articles.snippet: Bank of America, struggling with mounting losses at Merrill Lynch, would be the second bank after Citigroup to receive an additional lifeline from the government.
articles.abstract: Bank of America, struggling with mounting losses at Merrill Lynch, would be the second bank after Citigroup to receive an additional lifeline from the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign of deepening fragility among the nation’s largest banks, the government is preparing to throw a new multibillion-dollar lifeline to Bank of America, several people briefed on the talks said Wednesday, the latest effort to stem a tide of growing losses in the financial system.

articles.headline: Tech Shows, and Writers, Uninspired
articles.snippet: So many electronics shows, but so few standout products. But maybe that new Palm Pre is worth a word or two.
articles.abstract: So many electronics shows, but so few standout products. But maybe that new Palm Pre is worth a word or two.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hey, boss  sorry for this really superlong e-mail message. But since you’re my editor, I figure you should be the first person to hear the bad news: I’ve got no column for this week.

articles.headline: Chávez Lets West Make Oil Bids as Prices Plunge
articles.snippet: The financial crisis is hurting Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez’s efforts to establish a Socialist-inspired state.
articles.abstract: The financial crisis is hurting Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez’s efforts to establish a Socialist-inspired state.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez, buffeted by falling oil prices that threaten to damage his efforts to establish a Socialist-inspired state, is quietly courting Western oil companies once again.

articles.headline: Swindlers Find Growing Market in Foreclosures
articles.snippet: A new breed of swindlers calling themselves “foreclosure rescue companies” is preying on desperate homeowners.
articles.abstract: A new breed of swindlers calling themselves “foreclosure rescue companies” is preying on desperate homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: As home values across the country continue to plummet, the authorities say a new breed of swindler is preying on the tens of thousands of homeowners desperate to avoid foreclosure.

articles.headline: Buyers for a Citigroup Fire Sale Have Probably Been Singed, Too
articles.snippet: Citigroup wants to sell unprofitable businesses and troublesome assets, but investors wonder whether other companies will have the will or the means to buy them.
articles.abstract: Citigroup wants to sell unprofitable businesses and troublesome assets, but investors wonder whether other companies will have the will or the means to buy them.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Citigroup and its embattled leader, Vikram S. Pandit, the terrible ifs are accumulating.

articles.headline: War on Hamas Saps Palestinian Leaders
articles.snippet: The Palestinian Authority’s top party, Fatah, seems increasingly marginalized, even in the cities it controls.
articles.abstract: The Palestinian Authority’s top party, Fatah, seems increasingly marginalized, even in the cities it controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel hoped that the war in Gaza would not only cripple Hamas, but eventually strengthen its secular rival, the Palestinian Authority, and even allow it to claw its way back into Gaza.

articles.headline: Madoffs Shared Much; Question Is How Much
articles.snippet: Whether Ruth Madoff knew of her husband’s scheme or whether she didn’t are two unnerving possibilities.
articles.abstract: Whether Ruth Madoff knew of her husband’s scheme or whether she didn’t are two unnerving possibilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: To friends, they were “Bernie-and-Ruth” or “Ruth-and-Bernie,” a pair so inseparable that you wouldn’t mention one without the other. After nearly 50 years of marriage, they worked in the same Midtown Manhattan office, they traveled together, and they dined together night after night, just the two of them.
articles.byline: By David Segal and Alison Leigh Cowan

articles.headline: Where Is Oil Going Next?
articles.snippet: As demand for oil has plunged, companies up and down the energy pipeline are acting in ways that would have been unimaginable until recently.
articles.abstract: As demand for oil has plunged, companies up and down the energy pipeline are acting in ways that would have been unimaginable until recently.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — From the Indian Ocean to the South Atlantic to the Gulf of Mexico, giant supertankers brimming with oil are resting at anchor or slowly tracing racetrack patterns through the sea, heading nowhere.

articles.headline: Security Net Wraps Capital for Inaugural
articles.snippet: Though no credible threat has been detected, the security measures are by far the most extensive for a swearing-in.
articles.abstract: Though no credible threat has been detected, the security measures are by far the most extensive for a swearing-in.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal authorities have begun to seal off a security zone extending miles from the Capitol, where President-elect Barack Obama will be sworn in on Tuesday, drawing on disparate lessons gleaned from terrorist attacks in London and Mumbai, the Sept. 11 attack at the Pentagon and even annual Fourth of July celebrations on the Mall.

articles.headline: Israel Shells U.N. Site in Gaza, Drawing Fresh Condemnation
articles.snippet: In addition to the strike on the United Nations compound, an Israeli bombing killed a senior Hamas official in Gaza.
articles.abstract: In addition to the strike on the United Nations compound, an Israeli bombing killed a senior Hamas official in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel stepped up its 20-day-old offensive against the Islamic group Hamas on Thursday, shelling the headquarters of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency and other buildings in central Gaza. The strikes intensified condemnation of Israel, already heated because of the number of civilian deaths, and further strained fraught relations with the agency that provides aid to Palestinian refugees.
